title: How to study as well as work at the same time - Quora

response.answer_text: With effort. I am not sure how else to say it.  I have experience working and going to school- I did it for 3 years of undergrad and 3 years of graduate school (with a year in between).  That spanned two different employers and a career transition (as well as a change in educational focus).  On a personal note, it also spanned the birth of 3 children. There were a lot of days when I woke up and was less than motivated to go to work.  There were days when I got off work and didn't want to go to school.  Most nights, by the time I got home, I didn't want to study. Things I did that helped compensate for the load: I took one day (in my case Sunday) all of the way off.  No work.  No school.  No homework.  I went to church, I spent time with my wife and later with my kids, and we usually went over and spent time with other people we enjoyed spending time with.I gave myself a break after I got home.  No matter how much homework I had, I usually gave myself at least an hour to decompress (which usually included eating dinner) when I first got home.  I did better on reapplying myself to my homework after a break.  Much more so if the break involved physical activity, like playing with my young children.I prioritized like crazy.  Getting things done was a priority, but getting an A on every assignment or exam was a luxury.  I learned to be very happy with Bs during my graduate school years.I looked for easy classes any time I wasn't directly interested in learning the material (which is to say, when accomplishing elective classes).I put off a lot of things.  Many household repairs waited until I graduated or at least the week or two between semesters (I also attended summer sessions most years).  We didn't travel much except one trip a year to visit my in-laws, roughly a 30 hour drive.  We didn't often go try that new restaurant or go see that new movie.But all of those compensating steps didn't make it stop being a huge amount of effort.  So just commit to finishing, then dig in and get it done. Good luck.

Combining work and study isn't an easy task as it comes with its pros and cons. However, once the decision is taken, you can utilize the following tips to balance your work and study; - Try to inform the management at your workplace about it to avoid conflict of interests. - Have a financial backup and ensure that your loved ones support you as that emotional reinforcement cannot be ignored. - Inform your tutors that you're a working student so that they can create a flexible schedule for you. - Get your lecture timetable as early as you can for early planning. - Stick to the given schedule and ensure that you meet your set targets. - Rewarding yourself for achieving the above goals isn't also a crime. - Get one or two of your colleagues at work who can still fill in your vacuum at the workplace whenever possible. - Make friends with your classmates and figure out the dependable ones among them that can keep you posted.  - It shouldn't all be about your work and school, so spare some time to pamper yourself. - For goodness sake, kindly take a break whenever you feel overwhelmed with your studies Ifeoluwa Egbetade's answer to What do you do when you are overwhelmed by the study material you have to study for an exam?. - Get yourself a study environment that you can easily maintain. - Remember to organize yourself as well as your resource materials and don't miss out on any study group activities if you have one. - Keep your mind at rest and never forget that you've got all it takes to succeed. You can also check this link for more insights; 14 Success Precepts to Always Keep Handy Cheers.

To study and work at the same time may be difficult.If you have to work, take twelve credits or less depending on the requirements to study at the institution of your choice.That study load will give you some time to work.You can also enroll in evening or in Saturday classes and work during the week.  Cconsider dividing the day to work and study as follows:    About four to six hours to sleep.    About seven to ten hours to work.    About six to eight hours to study.These times are approximate and rotational.That means that you have to accomodate all your daily needs and change the schedules to fit your purpose for each day.If your college does not require every day attendance to classes you may work out special arrangements with your professors to accomodate study and work itineraries.If your college requires every day attendance to classes, consider a free attendance university or internet accredited classes.Any way you go, keep in mind that you need to study most of your time after classes.

I am currently working with TUV SUD South Asia Pvt Ltd, also not to forget I am pursuing my CMA for which I must write exams twice a year. This article is not about me, it is about all those who are struggling whether they should study or work or do both? I personally believe that everything is possible, nothing is rocket science. It is just that the situation is difficult but it is not impossible, there are few tips and experience in this article which will surely help you out in this sort of situation. So very importantly, you need to ask yourself about further studies which you are planning to do. How beneficial it will be for you in terms of Knowledge, in terms of your career scope and get the information about the structure and difficulty level of your exams. If it is easy, there is no point in thinking all this. You can start working without any second thought, You can simply take one weeks off and clear the exams with flying colors. Now chances are high that these types of PROFESSIONAL Exams will be difficult, you need to give your best to crack them but that doesn’t mean you must be at home and study all the time. Life will become boring, hence it is very much advisable to go out and gain some practical knowledge. Trust me guys, I have seen people with so many degrees but no practical idea about what and how markets is doing? Few Tips about your study schedule: 1. Always plan your studies, immediately when you get to know about your syllabus, based on chapters and subject you can allocate time to each subject. 2. Stop Wasting Time, people. 3. Make the most of your weekends, because if you sacrifice some fun now, you can enjoy later without any regrets. 4. Prefer online Virtual Classes over personal tuitions. 5. Stick to the modules provided by institution. Tips about your Job/work profile/ to be employer: 1. Make sure the employer is aware about you pursuing your professional courses, it will ultimately help you only, if you are lucky enough because they will support you and groom you. 2. Never ever work or reject the offer for money, because at this stage of your life knowledge is important. 3. Discuss about the leave period with your Reporting Manager and make sure You get leaves for at least 3 Weeks. 4. While working always try to link the dots, try to relate practical procedures with your curricular. 5. Last but not the least, Be Patient!! At the end, all that matters is your thought about the situation. If you set this thing in your mind that you can do it then nobody can stop you. All the Best.

Not easy, especially if it lasts for years. But can be done and was done by many people. Just try not to be cornered by deadlines, so you can somewhat respond to the needs of your body. Otherwise, if your physical and/or psychological health will factor in, the challenge might start snowballing.  Start easy and be active. Respond to the job requirements unconditionally and quickly, so you do not think about it twice. Then study and do your homework also immediately - do not procrastinate. If feel energy left, do not load yourself with more other stuff, take it easy and relax or, better, do sports. Time will come when you will need to work harder, so do not stretch yourself, do things and sleep well.  And remember, it will end. Until then, no deviation from the set plan.

You prioritize your time appropriately. When I was working on my second college degree, I had days where I worked, and then other days I went to school. On all days I would be studying unless school was out (winter or spring vacation), in which case I would still be working at my part-time job. I will also acknowledge that for the two years I was going back to school, I had a lot of seven-day work weeks because of my studies and employment. However, it was worth it in the end to get a decent job in a career I’d worked hard for, which in this case was medical transcription.

Have a good night's sleep.

Time management is something tricky to take care of. But it is very easy and entertaining if you are able to do it as it takes out boredom from your life and makes your life more interesting and challenging. How you go about it, depends on how related your job and study are. If they have a lot in common, for example, someone enrolled in a technical course doing similar technical stuff at job would find it easier to manage both. But if your job has nothing similar with what you want to study then free timings are all you need to focus first. Besides, it also depends upon nature of work at job, for example, if it is a desk job, then you can manage to study in free time but if it involves too much physical activity then most probably you will be too tired to do study afterwards. Since from your question, it is not very clear about what kind of job you do, how much free time you get and what course or type of study you want to do. So I will suggest you to usual approach. Make a list of free time you get in a week. Let’s say, you get 4 hours free everyday on weekday and 6 on weekends. Then write down those number of hours in which you can sit and study properly without any disturbance and also think about some hours which you are free but you can’t sit and study ( if you commute through public mode of transport or walk to your office, this would come under this category). Then analyze your syllabus and fix some topics for each day according to available time slots. You can go for some audio/video lectures for the duration in which you commute to office by some public transport. Since, in any study, revision plays an important role; so you can keep those hours which are not that disturbance free for revision and keep continuous longer hours for making notes and reading new things. Hope that helps. Best of Luck!

Get a big calendar or planner, start with what you cant change. Like classes, list the mandatory lessons, groups, appointments, study blocks. Look at work, is it part time, casual, are there regular shifts? If not, can you get regular shifts. It’s about having structure and routine. Look at what is left, is there enough space left for your time? Just like you should always pay yourself some of your wages, you need to have guilt free down time. And if there’s not enough time for you, change something. Whether you roster yourself ‘off’ every second Saturday and Tuesday, or Monday mornings and Friday nights, you have to give yourself a break. And say no to people, if you want to stay in bed and read a book, do it. If you want to go see a movie, do it. Pencil yourself in to your schedule. If you don’t give yourself some quiet time to relax and recharge, you wont need to balance the rest, because you’ll end getting fired from work and dropping out of school.

Lots of full-time students have part-time jobs. Lots of people in full-time work study part time, including full degree courses. It is not advisable to attempt to work 40 hours a week on a job and 40 hours a week on studying. It is rarely practical to schedule this, and against all the regulations of universities I know, who usually set a limit of 16 hours per week (paid or not) for students who are registered as full-time. About half this would be reasonable. Note that working students sometimes get conflicts when the employer wants (needs) the student for something urgent. In my experience students who work in a family business have this especially hard.

I am slightly confused: people worry about balance of job and life. You refer to study. Are you still a student? Do you already have a job? Assuming that you are still studying and have managed to get a job, I would suggest the following: (a) Remember Study assumes more importance and priority than the job at this stage. (b) Have a fixed time for study and if there is a spill over, do provide for it from the time allotted to job (c) Normally do not accept time-critical jobs as any extra time for the job might affect the study. However, if it becomes unavoidable, let it be a short duration one and in this case, make an exception to the above rules. The job has to finish within the time allotted. Good luck.

Thanks for the A2A. It's pretty difficult, but it is possible. My first suggestion would be to quit studying. You only need it when you are preparing for the test. Otherwise, turn your study time into a fun and enjoable activity. There is really no universal approach here - anything can be fun and enjoyable if you find it to be so. So, this is the first and the essential step - try to find a way to make your studying enjoyable. Once you add a bit of focus to it, and a self-correction of your own mistakes, this will also become productive. Consequently, you will have a reverse situation - you will enjoy learning things so much that you will find it hard to stop. And the advice here would be simple - take breaks, breath some fresh air, do a bit of simple physical exercises after 1 hour of learning and so on.

Balancing studying and work is difficult. The most important factor in managing this balance is discipline. Without knowing your daily routine or circumstances, I would advise you to schedule non negotiable study time into your day. This means that during this time you are unavailable for anything else. The big issue with work is that people are tired and when they come home they sit down to relax. It is very difficult to get motivated to study from this position. Your dedicated study time should be built into your daily routine either immediately before or after work. Then you can relax. Focus on identifying key areas of the curriculum and practice answering exam questions as much as possible. Regular study will compound your efforts over time and will reduce the stress on you immediately before the exam. Best of luck
